title: Lesson 12: Cramer's Rule
objectives: Apply Cramer's rule to solve systems

cards.front: What is Cramer's rule for solving \( A\vec{x} = \vec{b} \)?
cards.back:
For each variable \( x_i \):

\( x_i = \frac{\det(A_i)}{\det(A)} \)

where \( A_i \) is matrix \( A \) with column \( i \) replaced by \( \vec{b} \).

cards.front: What is the geometric insight behind Cramer's rule?
cards.back:
Coordinates can be represented using signed areas/volumes instead of dot products.

The y-coordinate equals the signed area of the parallelogram formed by \( \hat{i} \) and the vector, divided by the unit parallelogram area.

cards.front: Why does Cramer's rule use determinant ratios?
cards.back:
When a matrix transforms space, all parallelograms scale by \( \det(A) \).

So: transformed area \( = \det(A) \times \) original area

Solving for original coordinates: divide the transformed area by \( \det(A) \).

Only when \( \det(A) \neq 0 \).

The matrix must be invertible, guaranteeing exactly one solution exists.

No. Gaussian elimination is faster for large systems.

Cramer's rule is valuable for understanding the geometric relationship between determinants and coordinates, not for practical computation.
